'''Steven Ira Hofstetter''' (born September 11, 1979) is an American comedian and television personality. His [[YouTube]] channel currently has over 90 million views.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/thehofstetter/|title=Steve Hofstetter|website=YouTube|accessdate=May 17, 2018}}</ref> He is the host of ''Finding Babe Ruth'' on FS1,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/mlb/just-a-bit-outside/story/finding-babe-ruth-steve-hofstetter-tv-special-fox-sports-fs1-jabo-rob-neyer-102315|title=JABO correspondent Steve Hofstetter tries to answer how good Babe Ruth would be if he were playing today|date=October 23, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> a regular panelist on ''MLB Now'' on MLB Network<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/video/topic/7417714/v676537483/steve-hofstetter-joins-brian-kenny-live-on-mlb-now|title=Steve Hofstetter on MLB Now - 05/10/2016|website=MLB.com|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> and was the host and executive producer of "Laughs" on Fox television stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/steve-hofstetter-brings-laughs-to-fox-tv_b233940|title=TVNewser - Jobs in TV News|website=www.mediabistro.com|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
As a radio personality, he hosted ''Four Quotas'', which aired twice per week on [[Sirius Satellite Radio]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20041211183649/http://www.stevehofstetter.com/quotas/]</ref> and ''The [[National Lampoon (magazine)|National Lampoon]] Radio Sports Minute (Or So)'' which aired in over 180 different markets. A print version of the ''Sports Minute'' runs in many papers, including the ''[[Rocky Mountain News]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minuteorso.com/|title=Steve Hofstetter's Sports Minute or So|website=www.minuteorso.com|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
Hofstetter has written for outfits like ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'', ''[[ESPN]]'' and ''[[Sports Illustrated for Kids]]''. He was a weekly columnist for ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/writers/steve_hofstetter/archive/index.html|title=SI.com - Steve Hofstetter - Writer Archive<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502174019/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/writers/steve_hofstetter/archive/index.html|archivedate=May 2, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> where his "Stand Up Guy" ran every Monday morning in Scorecard.
Hofstetter has made a number of television appearances, including [[ESPN]]'s ''[[Quite Frankly]]'',{{fact|date=June 2018}} Showtime's ''White Boyz in the Hood'',{{fact|date=June 2018}} [[VH1]]'s ''[[VH1 Top 20 Video Countdown|Countdown]]'', ABC's ''[[Barbara Walters Special]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comixny.com/event.aspx?eid=181|title=comixny.com|website=www.comixny.com|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> and CBS's ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montclairtimes.com/NC/0/543.html|title=North Jersey - Montclair|website=North Jersey|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> He has also been featured by local news programs in Boston, Atlanta, Louisville, Tulsa, Miami, and many other markets. He is a frequent guest on radio stations all over the country, especially sports stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vids.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=vids.individual&videoid=1016912015|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121229150451/http://vids.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=vids.individual&videoid=1016912015|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 29, 2012|title=Featured Content on Myspace|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Background== Hofstetter grew up in the New York City borough of [[Queens]], living at various times in [[Briarwood, Queens|Briarwood]], [[Forest Hills, Queens|Forest Hills]] and [[Rego Park, Queens|Rego Park]].<ref>Silverberg, Alex. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070613175543/http://www.stevehofstetter.com/reviewstemplate.cfm?ID=239 "Comic Thanks His Queens Upbringing"], copy of article from ''The Queens Tribune'', July 6, 2007. Archived from [http://www.stevehofstetter.com/reviewstemplate.cfm?ID=239 the original] on June 13, 2007. "Hofstetter has been all around Queens.. He spent his younger years in Briarwood before moving on to Forest Hills, and finally settling down in Rego Park for the duration of his teen years."</ref>
In 1997, Hofstetter graduated from [[Hunter College High School]] and in 2002, received his B.A. from [[Columbia University]]'s [[Columbia University School of General Studies|School of General Studies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.gs.columbia.edu/cgi-any/newspages.dll/pages?sitename=OWLNT&record=239&htmlfile=newspages3_AdFeature.htm|title=Alumni|website=www.alumni.gs.columbia.edu|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> At Columbia, he wrote for the ''[[Columbia Spectator]]''<ref>[http://www.columbiaspectator.com/media/storage/paper865/news/2002/05/01/Opinion/Parting.Shots-2039092.shtml]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> and was President of the [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] fraternity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sigep.org/blog/recruiting-steve-hofstetter.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122232215/http://www.sigep.org/blog/recruiting-steve-hofstetter.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 22, 2014|title=Sigma Phi Epsilon – Building Balanced Men|website=www.sigep.org|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbiasigep.org/history/|title=History|website=Columbia Sigma Phi Epsilon|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
Hofstetter is an avid supporter of the [[New York Mets]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stevehofstetter.com/bio.cfm|title=Steve Hofstetter, Comedian - Download your free comedy album now!|website=www.stevehofstetter.com|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> He is Jewish.
==Career== === ''Laughs'' === In August 2014, ''Laughs'' debuted on [[Fox Television]], with Hofstetter serving as executive producer and host. ''Laughs'' is a half-hour showcase show for standup comedians.<ref>[https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/fox-television-stations-sets-summer-test-runs-for-three-series-1201251348/ Fox Television Stations Sets Summer Test Runs for Three Series], ''Variety''</ref>
Shortly after the first episode premiered, [[SAG/AFTRA]] issued a "Do Not Work" notice to its members due to Fox's choice to make the show a non-union production. This touched off a controversy as to whether or not all television shows should be union productions, and Hofstetter took the brunt of the criticism.<ref>http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/news/2014/08/11/actors-union-lambastes-the-laughing-derby-co-owner.html</ref>
In December 2014, FOX Television announced a 20-episode extension of the series, bringing the total first season run to 39 episodes.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/stevehofstetter/posts/10154969870960604</ref>
=== "The Heckler Destroyer" === Hofstetter earned a reputation for lashing out at [[heckler]]s,<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/columnist/talkingtech/2014/08/01/celebrity-talking-tech-mining-heckles-for-youtube-views/13427541/], ''USA Today''</ref> and some of his anti-heckler YouTube clips reached over five million views. His channel reached over 90 million in total. Hofstetter credits the popularity to justice. He told the ''Orlando Sentinel'', "People like seeing other people get what they deserve" and "You can't fake a heckler clip. People are excited to see someone who's ruining everyone else's time get their comeuppance."<ref>[http://www.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment/tv/tv-guy/os-steve-hofstetter-good-to-be-kingmaker-20140730-post.html], ''Orlando Sentinel''</ref>
=== Sports and comedy ===
Though a comedian by trade, Hofstetter is also a sports writer. He has served as the Senior Comedy Correspondent for [[FOX Sports]]' "Just a Bit Outside".<ref>{{cite tweet|user=FOXSports|author=FOX Sports|number=566323676518166529|date=13 February 2015|title=Meet @SteveHofstetter, the new #JABO (Just A Bit Outside) Senior Comedy Correspondent! First up: Josh Hamilton.}}</ref>
A former ''Sports Illustrated'' columnist, Hofstetter is also the co-creator of "Hofstetter's Jerk of the Week", a satirical sports website that chronicled the misdeeds of athletes. Now defunct, the site earned much publicity, including from ''Sports Illustrated'', [[CNN]], ''[[USA Today]]'', and dozens of local newspapers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.gs.columbia.edu/cgi-any/newspages.dll/pages?record=51&bid=&nfid=&htmlfile=newspages3_Alumni.htm|title=Alumni|website=www.alumni.gs.columbia.edu|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
Hofstetter has also written for ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maximmagazine.com/articles/index.aspx?a_id=5242|title=Maxim|website=Maxim|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> ''[[ESPN Magazine]]''{{'}}s "The Jump",<ref>http://espn.go.com/magazine/jump_020816_strike.html</ref> and [[NHL.com]]. The ''[[New York Times]]'' featured Hofstetter in a half-page article about how he infuses sports into his comedy, and he is now a frequent guest of many sports radio stations, especially [[ESPN]] affiliates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vids.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=vids.individual&videoID=1016912015|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121203165539/http://vids.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=vids.individual&videoID=1016912015|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 3, 2012|title=Featured Content on Myspace|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
Hofstetter wrote ''National Lampoon's Balls'' in the summer of 2007.
=== Pay-What-You-Want === In December 2007, Hofstetter announced his new album, ''Dark Side of the Room''. While the album has a shelf date of March 2008, listeners are allowed to download it directly from his website with "Pay-What-You-Want" à la [[Radiohead]]'s 2007 album ''[[In Rainbows]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnsoncitypress.com/Detail.php?Cat=ENTERTAINMENT&ID=60999|title=Johnson City Press:|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
Hofstetter is believed to be the first comedian to try the new model, and early returns reaffirm Radiohead's success.<ref>http://www.last100.com/2007/12/14/comedian-hofstetter-experiments-with-pay-what-you-want-and-provides-numbers/</ref>
=== Hofstetter vs. The Cable Guy ===
In March 2006, Hofstetter and [[Razor & Tie]] announced the April 4 release of ''Cure for the Cable Guy'', a 45-minute CD/DVD that featured a cover with a [[Larry the Cable Guy]] Doll hanging by a coax cable. The disc earned ''Stuff Magazine''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s "Album cover of the month". Later that week, Larry the Cable Guy's new film debuted and was universally panned. Several movie reviewers discussed Hofstetter's album, including the ''Orlando Sentinel''{{'}}s Roger Moore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deseretnews.com/movies/view/1,1257,425000817,00.html|title=Your Family's Media Guide - Ok.com<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930191303/http://deseretnews.com/movies/view/1,1257,425000817,00.html|archivedate=September 30, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Moore's review was picked up by dozens of papers across the country, including the ''Chicago Tribune'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://metromix.chicagotribune.com/movies/mmx-060324-movies-review-larry,0,648696.story?coll=mmx-movies_top_heds |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311023456/http://metromix.chicagotribune.com/movies/mmx-060324-movies-review-larry,0,648696.story?coll=mmx-movies_top_heds |archivedate=March 11, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ''Denver Post'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/movies/ci_3639437|title=“Cable Guy” needs healthy joke infusion|date=March 25, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref> and ''Columbus Dispatch''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mix971.net/events/calendar.php?story=dispatch/2006/03/25/20060325-B4-02.html|title=Mix971.net: The Leading Mix Site on the Net<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814004431/http://www.mix971.net/events/calendar.php?story=dispatch%2F2006%2F03%2F25%2F20060325-B4-02.html|archivedate=August 14, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Hofstetter did radio interviews about the album, including one with Philadelphia's [[Kidd Chris]] show, where Hofstetter spoke with Larry the Cable Guy's alter ego, Dan Whitney. Whitney ended the interview with his catch phrase, "Git-R-Done."
The album's cover was compared to the [[Sex Pistols]]' "Pink Floyd Sucks" T-shirts. [[Allmusic]]'s Bret Love wrote, "Hofstetter effectively rebels against the mainstream by positioning himself as the antithesis of the world's most popular comedian. What could be more punk rock than that?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shop.vh1.com/Cure-for-the-Cable-Guy-Standup-Comedy_stcVVproductId4269323VVcatId424044VVviewprod.htm|title=New Music Videos, Reality TV Shows, Celebrity News, Pop Culture - VH1|website=VH1|accessdate=May 9, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000728/http://shop.vh1.com/Cure-for-the-Cable-Guy-Standup-Comedy_stcVVproductId4269323VVcatId424044VVviewprod.htm|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In July, an article in the ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' quoted Whitney as saying Hofstetter had been hurtful, and Whitney's manager criticizing Hofstetter for "trying to make a buck". In response, Hofstetter posted a video on [[YouTube]] explaining his stance on the Cable Guy and his comedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mVzeT6KofYM|title=Why I Cured the Cable Guy (Steve Hofstetter)|first=|last=Steve Hofstetter|date=July 6, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=May 9, 2018|via=YouTube}}</ref>
